title: Cyber Daily: U.S. and Europeans Parley in Pittsburgh on Tech, Trade and China
text:
Some European regulators have recently moved to stop data transfers to the U.S., citing last year's court ruling that toppled the Privacy Shield agreement, the deal that allowed for easy trans-Atlantic data transfers. The EU also fears U.S. government surveillance of Europeans' data.

The result? Confusion, as companies look for legal ways to move information between countries. Although some key officials from both sides will be in Pittsburgh, no Privacy Shield replacement deal is expected to be unveiled.

Trade and Technology Council

EU trade commissioner Valdis Dombrovskis acknowledged recent tensions with the U.S. but added, â€˜we agree these issues should not cloud our judgment.'

A high-level trade and technology meeting set for Pittsburgh on Wednesday is aimed at smoothing over squabbles between the U.S. and European Union, even as policy disagreements over China threaten to further strain relations.

The new cross-Atlantic initiative, called the Trade and Technology Council, "is not about any specific third country," Valdis Dombrovskis, the EU's executive vice president and trade commissioner, told reporters in a summary of Europe's view.

China isn't mentioned by name in any agenda items for Wednesday's meeting, but topics such as the "misuse of technology threatening security and human rights" give a clear opening to a Chinese discussion. Beijing has been accused of using tech to surveill the Muslim Uyghurs in Xinjiang, which it denies, and also uses a social credit system to score the behavior of businesses and individuals.

More Cyber News

U.S. deports a high-profile hacker to Russia before the end of his prison sentence. Alexei Burkov, 31, was placed on a commercial airline flight on Monday after being released from federal prison last month, at least a year before his incarceration was due to finish. (WSJ)

A lawyer for Mr. Burkov declined to comment on the reason for his release. The Justice Department also declined to comment beyond confirming Mr. Burkov was released from prison Aug. 25. Court proceedings in recent months before he was released are sealed. Russian officials didn't immediately respond to a request for comment.

Mr. Burkov was extradited to the U.S. in 2019 from Israel on hacking-related charges, including fraud, identity theft, computer intrusion and money laundering. He pleaded guilty to running web forums where hackers swapped stolen data and was sentenced to nine years in prison last June, which included time served while being held in custody by the Israelis since 2015.

Backdoor: Microsoft warned customers of malware that can create a backdoor into networks by gaining access to Microsoft's Active Directory software. Called FoggyWeb, the tool is another used by the hackers who corrupted software from networking company SolarWinds. Other hackers have been using FoggyWeb since April, Microsoft said. (ZDNet)

DDoS attacks disrupt internet phone services. Customers of voice-over-IP provider Bandwidth.com are seeing intermittent outages resulting from distributed denial-of-service campaigns begun Sept. 25. Inbound and outband calls are being disrupted, Bandwidth.com said. Similar attacks caused outages at VOIP.ms earlier this month, with hackers demanding a ransom to stop the onslaught. (Bleeping Computer)

Incident-reporting bill would require disclosure of ransom payments. A bipartisan bill introduced in the Senate on Tuesday calls for companies with more than 50 employees, plus other organizations, to tell the federal government when they pay ransom to hackers. (Bloomberg Government)

Warby Parker discloses cyberattack probe before public offering planned for this week. The Office for Civil Rights within the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services is investigating Warby Parker Inc.'s response to a 2018 data breach, the eyewear company said in its S-1 filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. (Fortune)

Warby Parker notified customers at the time that their prescription and other personal data was compromised. The OCR, which enforces healthcare data protection regulations, opened its probe in 2019, the filing said.

24%

Percentage of 400 U.S. business and tech professionals who said they have a "zero trust" approach to cybersecurity in place, according to a survey from IT trade group CompTIA. That is the least used among nine core cyber practices the group researched.

Privacy

Facebook's plans for preteens draw privacy concerns. Internal Facebook documents viewed by The Wall Street Journal show the company formed a team to study preteens, set a three-year goal to create more products for them and commissioned strategy papers about long-term business opportunities presented by these potential users. In one presentation, it contemplated whether there might be a way to engage children during play dates. (WSJ)

Federal privacy law forbids data collection on children under 13, and lawmakers have criticized tech companies for not doing more to protect kids online from predators and harmful content.

TikTok and YouTube have in the past few years each reached settlements for allegedly violating federal privacy laws protecting children, and have announced tighter rules since then to further protect young users.

"Astro, stop looking at me." Amazon's new Astro Home Robot is an autonomous bot powered by Alexa designed to patrol your home and check out activity detected by Amazon's Ring smart doorbells. The bot creates and stores a 3-D map of your home, so you can say "Go to the kitchen" and it will zoom there. It has a periscope with a 12-megapixel camera that can rise up to 42 inches. (WSJ)

For those concerned about limiting what Astro can know or do, it has a mic/camera shutoff privacy button. Also, users can create out-of-bounds zones that the robot won't cross, even if it detects activity there.
